messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] A different view...
messages.msgSnippet: Think about it it is your sword and you commission Nagayama to do a detailed oshigata. Would you (well YOU might) then invite him to post your oshigata for all
messages.messageBody:
Think about it it is your sword and you commission Nagayama to do a
detailed oshigata. Would you (well YOU might) then invite him to post
your oshigata for all the world to download and print on the net? Why
don't we ask Mishina Sensei...
-t

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] A different view...
messages.msgSnippet: Nope, looking at the same thing. I made a mistake. Still, you would think it would include an oshigata of the signture for the signed pieces. I think it is a
messages.messageBody:
Nope, looking at the same thing. I made a mistake. Still, you would think it
would include an oshigata of the signture for the signed pieces. I think it
is a bit ambiguous.

Gordon
-----Original Message-----
From: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...]
Sent: Thursday, July 03, 2003 1:43 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] A different view...


Gordon,
1) mumei Shizu Kaneuji, ha-watari 66.7 cm., sori 1.22 cm.

2) mei Tegai Kanenaga, ha-watari 67.0 cm., sori 1.7 cm

3) Mumei but attributed to "Chikakage" by Hon-ami Kochu (Kin-zogan-mei),
Ha-watari - 70.9 cm. / Sori : 2.6 cm.

etc...
Even the Kanabo has a length and sori specified. Not sure if we're
looking at the same links:


http://www007.upp.so-net.ne.jp/m-kenji/nagayama_oshigata/nagayama_front.htm

I can't comment on the merit of the remarks made under the Kanabo piece.
Your territory for sure.

Jim




Hi Jim and all,

I did not take a look at these until just now. I think that these are
hybred
oshigata as only width and curvature is given, but not a specific length
for
the blade. Also note in regard to the Kanabo information, no Yamato-den
style workmanship has been seen is false. I have a ko-wakizashi signed
Nanto
ju Kanabo Hayatonosho Masazane on the omote and kore wo Hosho utsusu
(this
is a Hosho copy) on the ura. The nakago has a ichimon style nakagojiri
with
higaki yasuri like Hosho works and the jigane is masame with a narrow
suguha
temper and nijuba, all typical of the Hosho school of the Yamato-den.
Remember, never say never.

Gordon

Gordon,
1) mumei Shizu Kaneuji, ha-watari 66.7 cm., sori 1.22 cm.

2) mei Tegai Kanenaga, ha-watari 67.0 cm., sori 1.7 cm

3) Mumei but attributed to "Chikakage" by Hon-ami Kochu (Kin-zogan-mei), Ha-watari - 70.9 cm. / Sori : 2.6 cm.

etc...
Even the Kanabo has a length and sori specified. Not sure if we're looking at the same links:

http://www007.upp.so-net.ne.jp/m-kenji/nagayama_oshigata/nagayama_front.htm

I can't comment on the merit of the remarks made under the Kanabo piece. Your territory for sure.

Jim

-----Original Message-----
From: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...]
Sent: Thursday, July 03, 2003 12:52 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] A different view...


Seems pretty clear that the oshigata in the link Tom posted are of
specific, individual swords given the exact dimensions and descriptive text
associated with each example.

Agreed that it would be very interesting to compare these new oshigata vs.
the traditional style of drawing vs. the actual swords. A project for you
sword guys...

Jim

Peter-
I'll be corrected if I am wrong, but I am almost certain that
what you are seeing on the website are specific oshigata of
individual swords. In the Dokuhon, the oshigata especially for the
general characteristics of individual schools, the images are
"idealized" like in Teiryo Yoji. Sometimes I have found those to be
"not quite" what I am seeing in a sword. Takes some imagination to
reconcile what the book shows and what you see in hand. It is still
the best book for kantei.
These oshigata are REAL swords and it really would be
enlightening to compare, sword, photo, oshigata and "Diagrammatic
Oshigata" side by side...
-t

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] A different view...
messages.msgSnippet: Ron, I doubt that these  images start as presentations of specific swords. They look for like summary interpretations of what ALL the swords in the category
messages.messageBody:
Ron,
I doubt that these images start as presentations of specific swords. They
look for like summary interpretations of what ALL the swords in the
category should look - and 'feel' - like. Plus they do not appear to use
techniques of traditional Japanese graphics. A side-by-side comparison of a
picture and a sword would be wonderful, but I'd really like to see one of
these pictures being made. It is almost as if they are drawn from memory
based on a deeper understanding that a single sword could convey.
They sure are wonderful
PBleed


Jim, all -

I bet it would be interesting to see oshigata presented side-by-side of the
very same sword, using Nagayama's method (which apparently illustrates
details in a very graphic way) and the traditional (realist) method. One
method "draws in" the detail that should be noted while the other method
gives a very "true" illustration of the hamon, leaving finding and
understanding the subtle "detail" up to the viewer...something like that,
anyway.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, July 01, 2003 11:32 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] A different view...


Tom,
Any idea of how the oshigata are actually drawn? Looks like mottled gray
paper, the usual ink cake for the outline... opaque white pigment
(gouache?) for the hamon? Not sure how the hada is drawn in other than by
lots of sharp pencil work. Interesting way of representing utsuri and
antai. Reality can be marked on paper in many different ways. I wonder if
Nagayama-sensei's methods will catch on. Certainly different.

Jim



Now playing on another channel...

To members,

I have uploaded "Nagayama's Diagrammatic Oshigata" this morning. The
first upload includes 8 koto, 4 shinto and 2 shinshinto. Have a look
at it. Nagayama sensei is drawing oshigata energetically and I will
add them in due order.

Accesss : Click "Nagayama Diagrammatic Oshigata" on the front page of
my web site.
URLÝÝÝÝÝ : http://www007.upp.so-net.ne.jp/m-kenji/index.html

Mishina

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] A different view...
messages.msgSnippet: Nagayama sensei has a few oshigata like this in his book, and it helped me notice some things in the second sword that I bought a couple years ago that I would
messages.messageBody:
Nagayama sensei has a few oshigata like this in his book, and it helped
me notice some things in the second sword that I bought a couple years
ago that I would have missed otherwise. For a beginner, his oshigata
makes it absolutely clear what you are looking at and what you should be
looking for. A standard oshigata is also a good thing, but I think it is
more appropriate for well trained eyes who know what they are looking
at, and also know from experience what it would look like if they had
that particular sword in hand.

Anyway, having Nagayama sensei's oshigata coming up makes a good online
reference for smiths. It sounds like there may be more coming, and if
so, it's going to become a great quick reference guide.

- darcy

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] A different view...
messages.msgSnippet: Jim- We should be asking Mishina Sensei of course. If you look at the Kantei Dokuhon (connoiseurs ) you ll see the same style. I believe it was Cary who
messages.messageBody:
Jim-
We should be asking Mishina Sensei of course. If you look at
the Kantei Dokuhon (connoiseurs') you'll see the same style. I
believe it was Cary who pointed it out to me first, but his oshigata
are like negatives with black and white reversed. Usually the ji is
presented as white and the hamon is pencilled-in in black. This way
is "reversed" but also better approximates what the eye sees...
-t

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] A different view...
messages.msgSnippet: Tom, Any idea of how the oshigata are actually drawn?  Looks like mottled gray paper, the usual ink cake for the outline... opaque white pigment (gouache?) for
messages.messageBody:
Tom,
Any idea of how the oshigata are actually drawn? Looks like mottled gray paper, the usual ink cake for the outline... opaque white pigment (gouache?) for the hamon? Not sure how the hada is drawn in other than by lots of sharp pencil work. Interesting way of representing utsuri and antai. Reality can be marked on paper in many different ways. I wonder if Nagayama-sensei's methods will catch on. Certainly different.

Jim
